cards.back:
Vo = -(Rf/R1)V1 - (Rf/R2)V2 - ...

Or: Vo = -(A1V1 + A2V2 + ...)
where An = Rf/Rn

cards.front: Which op-amp configuration is the summing amp based on?
cards.back:
Inverting amplifier

Multiple inputs to inverting terminal, each through its own resistor, sharing common Rf.

cards.front: How to make a unity-gain summing amplifier?
cards.back:
Make all resistors equal: R1 = R2 = ... = Rf

Then Vo = -(V1 + V2 + ...)

cards.front: Why does summing amp invert the output?
cards.back:
Inputs connect to INVERTING terminal.

Same reason as basic inverting amp - it's built on that topology.

cards.front: How to design Rf and Rn for specific gains?
cards.back:
For gain An on input Vn:
Rn = Rf/An

Choose Rf first, then calculate each Rn.

Summing amp with Rf = R/n
(where n = number of inputs)

Vo = -(V1 + V2 + ... + Vn)/n

1. Audio mixers (combine channels)
2. Digital-to-Analog Converters (DACs)
3. Weighted voting systems
4. Signal processing

cards.front: Can summing amp mix AC and DC signals?
cards.back:
Yes! Each component is scaled by its gain.

Result: AC waveform offset by scaled DC level.

cards.front: How to verify individual gains A1 and A2?
cards.back:
Ground one input, measure gain with other:
• A1: Ground V2, measure Vo/V1
• A2: Ground V1, measure Vo/V2
